SCHOLARNOTE.P: She signed letters and poems as MWM. During her lifetime her work appeared before the public as by Lady Mary Wortley or The Right Honourable Lady M— W— M—. Montagu as the form of her surname was hardly ever used in England, only abroad. It was sometimes wrongly spelt with a final e.
This was not exactly a pseudonym, but the name of a part-autobiographical fictional character. Pope later employed it allusively as a nickname.
LMWM was celebrated by various writers and admirers under this name, as were many of her female writing contemporaries.
Pope then turned the name against her, using it as a coded allusion whose associations became steadily more and more dirty, lewd, and rapacious.

SHORTPROSE.P: The date of LMWM's birth is not known. She was the eldest in her family.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Mary Pierrepont (later LMWM) was born in London.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was baptised on this day at St Paul's Church, Covent Garden, London.

LMWM was an English noblewoman from a tender age, when her father acquired his first foothold in the peerage, as an earl. He later became a marquess and then a duke. Lady Mary's forebears on both sides included men and women distinguished for intellect as well as rank. As a young woman she claimed not to value family but only personal merit. In later years she gave various indications of family pride, and was grieved to see the title in the hands of her foolish and decadent nephew.
She writes occasionally like an Anglican, more often like a Deist or sceptic, and frequently as an anti-Catholic. In politics she was a pro-Robert Walpole Whig.

She writes freely about female sexual desire. After a passionate same-sex friendship in youth, it seems her feelings and her practice were heterosexual, if not possibly bisexual. She almost always presents herself as chastely monogamous, up to the moment when she fell in love with abandon in middle age. There is no evidence for the voracious promiscuity so often attributed to her.

Lady Mary's mother (Lady Mary Feilding, daughter of the Earl of Denbigh) had four babies in four years and died just before 8 December 1692.body/health Lady Mary later imagined her mother as an exceptional woman enduring with Christian stoicism her marriage to a rake she found it hard to respect.7-8

Lady Mary's father, Evelyn Pierrepont, was a youngest son, an able, forceful, libertine man who became an earl during her infancy, when the second of his elder brothers died. On 10 August 1715 he became Duke of Kingston. He married again once his first family were disposed of, and had two more daughters, whom LMWM never really considered as her sisters.

LMWM's closest sister, Frances, was married in 1714 to John Erskine, Earl of Mar. He led the first Jacobite rebellion to disaster in 1715 (leaving his wife and one-day-old daughter for this purpose without saying where he was going) and was condemned to exile. Frances, Lady Mar, facing enormous debts and torn between the hostile negotiations of her father and brother-in-law, was declared insane after fourteen years of marriage.74, 95, 282
Lady Mary's much-loved brother died of smallpox on 1 July 1713, not yet twenty-one, leaving a wife (not chosen by himself) and two small children.65
Lady Mary's younger sister, Evelyn, was married to Lord Gower on 13 March 1712; she died on 27 June 1727 after bearing in all eleven children.45, 2572: 80n3

LMWM said later that her education by a governess was the worst possible. But probably in her early teens, she resolved on stealing the Latin language, and set herself secretly to study five or eight hours a day in her father's library, whilst everybody else thought I was reading nothing but novels and romances.no. 743357no. 743
She was also taught French, Italian, and, as a potential political hostess, the art of carving meat.15

As a teenager Lady Mary Pierrepont formed a circle of friends which included members of the middle and upper classes: Lady Henrietta Cavendish Holles (later Lady Oxford), Dolly Walpole (later Lady Townshend) and the poor orphan Sarah Chiswell. Before her marriage came further important friendships with women, all having some literary component: with Mary Banks, Anne Justice, Philippa Mundy, and Frances Hewet (who was a generation older). The friendship with Anne Wortley was taken over by Anne's brother, who began dictating her letters to Lady Mary, in order to encode his own meaning in them.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Lady Mary Pierrepont eloped with Edward Wortley Montagu; they were married at Salisbury.

SHORTPROSE.P: They had been engaged in emotional negotiation for about two and a half years, including periods of estrangement. His proposals about disposing his eventual inheritance were unacceptable to Lady Mary's father. The pair at last eloped when she saw no other way to evade marriage to the man of her father's choice, from which she expected nothing but unhappiness; but she was or had very recently been in love with a third man, who remains unidentified.46, 47
Having eloped with no marriage contract, LMWM had thenceforth no money or possessions that legally belonged to her.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM bore her son, Edward.

SHORTPROSE.P: He grew up to cause her much pain by semi-criminal activities.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM spent most of her time at a handsome rented villa, Middlethorpe Hall near York, with her baby, often without her husband.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: Recently donated to the National Trust, this house has been functioning for some years as a historic house hotel36

SHORTPROSE.P: Her early experience of marriage was one of being separated from the scene of her social and socio-literary activity, thrown on her own resources as an anxious mother and a solitary writer.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM spent an exciting time in London as a member of the Whig elite now in power under George I.

SHORTPROSE.P: She frequented both of the incompatible court circles—those of the king and of the Prince and Princess of Wales—apparently in search of a power base.
At this time LMWM met and established friendships with writers, artists, and people of learning: Pope, Gay, Charles Jervas, and the Venetian philosophe Antonio Conti.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM was dangerously ill with smallpox.

SHORTPROSE.P: For two days she was near death. She recovered, but was left badly scarred and without any eyelashes.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM left London with her husband to travel to Turkey.

SHORTPROSE.P: He had been appointed British Ambassador to the Porte, or Ottoman Empire. Criss-crossing Europe (since they were recalled for further instructions to Hanover after they were already well on their way), Lady Mary had the opportunity to observe most of the kinds of political and national institution then in being: self-governing mercantile cities, princely states, and the imperial court of Vienna.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM and her husband crossed the recent battlefield of Peterwardein in Hungary.

SHORTPROSE.P: Bodies were still, after more than six months, lying unburied. This experience (her last before leaving Christian Europe for Islamic Turkey) probably helped to shape her lasting anti-war sentiments.politics

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM and her husband arrived at Belgrade, their first Turkish city; they stayed there three weeks.

SHORTPROSE.P: Here, in the house of an effendi she calls Achmet Beg, Lady Mary had her first lessons in Turkish literature and culture, and was favourably impressed with both.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM visited the women's public baths at Sofia in Bulgaria: a scene of female nudity which she later famously described.

SHORTPROSE.P: Montagu was unlike other female western travellers in describing the naked women as beautiful, not repellent; she declined to take off her clothes and join them.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM and her husband arrived at Adrianople, the site of the Sultan's court and so the centre of the Ottoman Empire.

SHORTPROSE.P: Here she pursued her researches into Turkish life. Unusually for a western visitor, she received and accepted a number of invitations into Turkish homes, i.e. harems.leisure activities

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM and her husband reached Constantinople.

SHORTPROSE.P: She lived there for a year, interrupted by time spent at the rural retreat of Belgrade Village near Constantinople. But even before they reached Turkey, a new administration in England had altered its policy and sent orders for Edward Wortley Montagu's recall from his post. His premature recall has created a general impression that he was no good at his job, but this is unfair. No matter how well he performed, the new ministry wanted their own man in post.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM and her husband sailed from Constantinople on their voyage home.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Mediterranean voyage felt like a course in ancient classical civilization. Lady Mary also visited the ruins of Carthage. Though so accepting and admiring of the Turks, she makes casually racist remarks about Africans.politics

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM crossed the Alps for the first time, with her husband.

CHRONSTRUCT.RESEARCHNOTE: phd: this date and the one below are old style whereas those above have been converted to new.
CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM visited Paris: she saw the sights and met many interesting people.
LMWM arrived home in London after her Turkish travels.
LMWM, in Constantinople, had her five-year-old son inoculated against smallpox.

SHORTPROSE.P: She had lost her brother to smallpox, and narrowly escaped herself. She probably went to Turkey primed with accounts which had reached the Royal Society in London of the Turkish practice of inoculation, and determined to discover this medical phenomenon for herself. The Embassy surgeon, Charles Maitland, shared her interest, and helped in the inoculation of young Edward with the old Turkish woman who was the leading practitioner in Constantinople.162

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: During a virulent smallpox epidemic, LMWM had performed on her three-year-old daughter the first inoculation in England.

SHORTPROSE.P: This operation too was performed by Charles Maitland (a little reluctantly: he knew he was risking his professional career). At his request, official observers attended. One of these, James Keith, who had lost several children to smallpox, waited only long enough to see that the child was recovering before enlisting Maitland to inoculate his surviving four-year-old son.

Though Montagu's precise contribution is hard to quantify, she was actively involved during the next several years in the struggle to naturalise inoculation: encouraging parents of her own class to inoculate their children and supporting them through the process. She was, she said, much pull'd about and solicited2:26 for her advice and superintendence by all who could make or claim the slightest acquaintance36 with her. She was also vilified in print and face to face by opponents of the new practice.2:2635-6

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: An anonymous author, apparently the country apothecary Cudworth Bruch, celebrated the memory of LMWM in The Triumph of Inoculation; a Dream.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: His name appears in manuscript on the title-page of the Bodleian Library copy.

SHORTPROSE.P: The author mentions his long-continued correspondence with her about inoculation. His vigorous mock-heroic casts anti-inoculationists as villains, ridicules them, and nevertheless implies that they are almost extinct. Montagu, a Circassian-garbed figure, conducts the new goddess Inoculatio to her throne after the rout of the evil and malignant power Variola.219 n64, 222

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM spent most of her summers at Twickenham, on the Thames near London.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her husband bought Savile House there in 1722, having apparently rented it from Sir Godfrey Kneller before that.

Lady Mary was pursued with letters of intellectual gallantry by Nicolas-François Rémond, a minor philosophe. He visited England at the time of the South Sea share fever; she says that having rejected his proffered love she agreed to be his financial adviser. When his money was lost in the crash (along with almost everyone else's), he chose to hold her responsible and made a determined attempt to blackmail her.

Lady Mary claimed that at every stage of her life she picked a few intimate friends and cared little for the opinions of anyone else. She always retained the highest opinion of her father's and husband's friends, Congreve and Addison. Of her friendships from early in George I's reign, that with Conti endured while those with Pope and Gay radically soured. After much speculation, the causes of her break with Pope remain unplumbed. Apparently she did something mortally to offend him: probably something specific in addition to the arrogance and unfemininity (as he would have seen it) and the Whiggery of her writing.

She now sought the friendship of those in political power, like James Craggs, Charlotte Clayton, and members of the royal family. But she was closest to outsiders like Lady Stafford (an almost certainly lesbian Frenchwoman disowned by her husband and living in England) and Molly Skerrett. Her friendship for Skerrett extended to Skerrett's lover, Sir Robert Walpole. Lord Hervey, another close friend, was an insider in politics but an outsider through his bisexuality and his aloof, cynical temperament. LMWM prided herself on the talent for friendship which enabled her never to offend or antagonise the quarrelsome Sarah, Duchess of Marlborough. During her years abroad, she collected and held on to a further idiosyncratic collection of friends.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM's sister Lady Mar arrived in London from Paris.

SHORTPROSE.P: A newspaper reporting Lady Mar's arrival said she was so disorder'd in her Head, that it is believed she'll scarce ever recover her Senses.267 From now until July, her English birth family and her Scottish relations by marriage struggled for possession of her person and income.267

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM's deranged sister, Frances, Lady Mar, was abducted and carried off by agents of her brother-in-law Lord Grange, in pursuit of his own financial interest.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: This was the same Lord Grange who later famously imprisoned his own wife on a remote island (St Kilda) after quarrelling with her about money.

SHORTPROSE.P: It seems unlikely that Lady Mar can have consented to this move, which was intended to take her from London to her husband's estates at Alloa in Scotland, where she had never been. Her husband's family claimed the move would benefit her health, while freely admitting that they desperately needed the income attached to her person, which would be worth far more in Scotland than in London. LMWM, with legal backing, intercepted the party on the road at Stevenage in Hertfordshire, and brought her sister back to London.279

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM's deranged sister Lady Mar was placed under her guardianship.

SHORTPROSE.P: Three weeks later a lunacy commission officially confirmed that she was insane. For the next eight years she remained in LMWM's care.282

While she had responsibility for Lady Mar, LMWM signed receipts twice a year for her sister's allowance. This was for half the sum which the Crown allocated for Lady Mar's support when it seized her rebel husband's estates; LMWM allowed the husband to retain the other half for his own use. She competed with Grange for the guardianship of her sister. Though Grange was openly in it for the money, Pope used this situation in representing Lady Mary as a miser. She herself said years later that even though her father was wealthy and her husband became by his own entrepreneurial abilities the richest commoner in England, she herself never had any money at her personal disposal.282, 347-8154

LMWM acted as patron to a number of writers (all male so far as is known), most notably Richard Savage and Henry Fielding, but also Edward Young and Samuel Boyse. Books to which she subscribed included works by Pope and Gay, by Montaigne, Voltaire, Paolo Sarpi (in French translation), and the composer Giovanni Buononcini. She subscribed to Cupid's Metamorphoses by William Pattison (a farmer's son), published by Curll on 16 December 1727 (dated 1728), to the Life of Cicero by Conyers Middleton (grandfather by marriage of Elizabeth Montagu and Sarah Scott), 1741, and to Sarah Fielding's Familiar Letters between the Principal Characters in David Simple, 1747. Besides more literary pursuits, she oversaw her daughter's education, and was a keen needlewoman, though some of her friends apparently found this hard to believe.263-5, 187-8, 194-5, 225n14, 265, 266, 357n8, 387, 536 1832: 19; 3: 18

She had her portrait painted again and again, often in several copies as gifts to friends. Jervas painted her as a shepherdess (a style in which he specialised) before her marriage. Jean-Baptiste Vanmour painted her probably twice while she was in Turkey. Kneller painted her in 1715, again (commissioned by Pope) in 1720, and probably again at an unknown date. In the second and third Kneller and in two portraits by Jonathan Richardson, she wears Turkish or semi-Turkish dress, brought back from her travels. Her friend Lady Oxford owned both a miniature by Christian Zincke and a half-length portrait by Charles da Rusca. An engraving by George Vertue of the Zincke miniature was arranged in a composite engraved picture with miniatures of Lady Oxford's daughter and son-in-law. A picture which Lady Mary had done as a gift for Algarotti remains untraced. This probably completes the roster of authentic portraits, but not of either engravings of these or of pictures doubtfully or wrongly said to represent her.91,142, 163, 92, 202, 381, 301-3, 365

From the late 1720s onwards, Lady Mary's life was punctuated by the regular appearance of new attacks by Alexander Pope in his poems: sometimes unmistakable, sometimes so concealed that probably only their immediate circles would recognise them for what they were.
Late in life LMWM said her health had always been naturally robust. But various bouts of ill-health (apart from the major episode of her smallpox) are recorded.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM was reported seriously ill during the period that her runaway schoolboy son was missing.
LMWM was dangerously ill, and attended by Dr Arbuthnot.
LMWM was again seriously ill, possibly as the aftermath of a row with her son.
LMWM's niece Lady Frances Pierrepont, an heiress, eloped from her care with a man whom her aunt considered a fortune-hunter.

SHORTPROSE.P: According to Lady Mary years later, the marriage did indeed lead her niece into a life of financial stringency and dependence on her brother.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM's son, having recently come of age, made a demand for family money; they had an acrimonious scene.

SHORTPROSE.P: He had been banished abroad with a tutor after repeatedly running away from school, accumulating debts, marrying at seventeen, and immediately deserting his wife. He confronted his mother in his father's absence to demand a legacy left by his grandfather.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM's daughter married Lord Bute in the parish of Marylebone, London.

SHORTPROSE.P: Lady Mary's husband strongly disapproved of his daughter's choice, and withheld the large dowry which was expected. Because of this, Bute's uncles also refused to come down with money. Because, in turn, of the prospect of poverty, Lady Mary also tried to dissuade her daughter. Both parents, however, attended the wedding. Though it is often supposed that Lady Mary and her daughter quarrelled over the wedding, it seems that they remained on good terms till late February 1738, when some unexplained quarrel happened after Lady Mary had stood godmother to her first grandchild.386

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM fell suddenly in love with Francesco Algarotti, a brilliant young middle-class Venetian making the tour of Europe.
LMWM proposed to Algarotti that she might move from England to Venice to be near him.

SHORTPROSE.P: Algarotti was bisexual, and well accustomed to using his charms to further his ambition. Lady Mary's passion continued, concealed from all but her friend Lord Hervey (who himself was smitten by Algarotti, and was wryly amused at finding himself her rival), for five years of almost uninterrupted separation. She and Algarotti were both in Turin for a time in 1741, and it seems that during that time they made some kind of break with each other. It is not known what, if anything, happened physically between these two. When Lady Mary again came into contact with Algarotti fifteen years after the break, her excitement (of the mind this time) was again heady. He too was clearly willing to renew the friendship, though his later feelings remain as opaque as his earlier ones.436-9, 560-1

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM left London, en route for Venice, secretly intending to live with Algarotti.

SHORTPROSE.P: She parted with her husband on amicable terms, telling him that she was travelling for the sake of her health, but that she had still to make the decision as to the best place in which to settle in Europe. She found the journey southwards exhilarating, even the crossing of the Alps.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM lived in Venice.

SHORTPROSE.P: She immensely enjoyed the social life. But still she was waiting, with decreasing hope, for Algarotti to join her.
In Venice Lady Mary ran a salon (as she had apparently never done in England).

Here she renewed old friendships (with Conti, for instance) and made new ones, most importantly with the Venetian noblewoman Chiara Michiel. This friendship was linked with another: with James Stuart Mackenzie, a young Scotsman of talent and charm, and the younger brother of Lady Mary's son-in-law Bute.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM, no longer expecting Algarotti to join her in Venice, travelled while she waited to plan her future.

SHORTPROSE.P: Though she was keeping herself at Algarotti's beck and call, she enjoyed a kind of Grand Tour, something which was not normally available to those of her sex or age. She stayed at Florence (where she again formed herself a literary circle), Rome (where she did extensive sight-seeing), and Naples, though she failed to get a sight of Herculaneum. She also visited Leghorn and Genoa.2:202-32

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM spent these months at Turin, while Algarotti was also there on a diplomatic mission.

SHORTPROSE.P: Here the pair evidently negotiated an end to their relationship. After this break, LMWM seems not to have thought of going home, but looked for some place where she might settle in Europe unmolested by gathering clouds of war.436-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM tried Genoa, Geneva, and Chambéry, but was driven from each either by the climate or the threat of invasion.
LMWM, in Genoa, involved herself in local politics, taking the Republic of Genoa's side in an international incident between it and Britain.

SHORTPROSE.P: A British ship had, said the Genoese, violated their neutrality by firing on a small boat suspected of being a smuggler. Each side took hostages, and the affair escalated. Lady Mary mobilised her contacts and sought to persuade the Prime Minister to get Britain to back down. In due course a British court vindicated her reading of the situation.442-3

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM lived in Avignon, where she fitted up a belvedere or study for herself on the Rocher-des-Doms.

SHORTPROSE.P: Avignon was not then part of France, but of the Papal States. This kept it safe from the threat of invasion as the rest of Europe was crossed and re-crossed by armies. LMWM became gradually more displeased with its role as a Jacobite centre, but was kept prisoner by the War of the Austrian Succession.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM involved herself again in politics, intervening with the duc de Richelieu, governor of Languedoc, on behalf of persecuted French Huguenots.
LMWM took a short tour by road and canal around the south of France, seeking somewhere to settle instead of Avignon.
LMWM spent a night under cannon fire in the citadel of Seravalle.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was making the dangerous journey from Avignon through war-ravaged North Italy, hoping to reach Venice. She survived this incident partly because of the escort provided by Count Ugolino Palazzi.478

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM lived mostly in the province of Brescia in North Italy.

SHORTPROSE.P: Kept at the town of Brescia initially by a severe fever, she was nursed by Ugolino Palazzi's mother, Countess Giuliana Palazzi. She then bought from Palazzi a house in the village of Gottolengo, called from its history the Castle. This remained her base for ten years. At first she divided her time between her Castle and her Dairy-House, an ornamental and profitable small-holding which she developed in a vineyard on the banks of the River Oglio. She made extended visits to Lovere on the shore of lago d'Iseo in the province of Bergamo. She bought a palazzo there too.2: 375-7, 3: 109-10100ff
As the years of her absence lengthened, her relation with her husband became less sustaining, though it remained friendly.
Their most frequent topic, a painful one to both, was their son's career as a debtor, trickster, and con-man, as well as a soldier and MP.

LMWM's relationship with daughter, interrupted for nearly a decade by their quarrel, resumed about the time that Lady Bute underwent a particularly protracted and dangerous childbirth. Lady Mary pressed her regularly for detail about her grandchildren, only one of whom she had ever seen.

At her Dairy-House LMWM bred poultry, made her own wine, and experimented with various new or unusual crops like tea and silkworms. She kept in touch with home by reading new publications sent to her order by various people, especially her daughter.2: 302-4, 407-8

She remarked with some pride on her hope of doubling her farming capital. She received a quarterly allowance all this time from her husband, and lived frugally except for her habit of acquiring property. It later emerged that Palazzi was known to others, though presumably not to her, as a professional bandit and extortioner—a not uncommon way of life among the Brescian nobility. By a series of ingenious ruses he succeeded in getting large sums of money from her over a period of years.2: 404396n5, 440, 474n47, 554

LMWM had trouble with her health in North Italy. After her initial, dangerous and prolonged fever in 1746 (which was probably malaria), she suffered a number of recurrences. She also went down with severe periodontal or gum disease. The ulcers in her mouth were so bad that a surgeon, hastily summoned, cauterized her gums with hot irons. He was none too sure that she would survive; but she did.480ff, 497, 498, 505-6 Before she finally left Italy she must have known that she had breast cancer.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After several years of thwarted attempts to leave Brescia for Venice, LMWM succeeded, in the face of actual physical threat from Palazzi, in getting away.

SHORTPROSE.P: Palazzi had accompanied her from Lovere to Gottolengo a couple of months earlier, and effectively prevented her from going further. She now had a hired carriage broken and her journey interrupted by a thug with a firearm. She made the discovery that all her property deeds had been stolen and blank paper left in their place. She was urged, under implicit threat of violence, to sign a disclaimer exonerating Palazzi from any wrong-doing. At her absolute refusal to sign, Palazzi backed down, perhaps owing to the influence of his aunt, who seems to have sided with Lady Mary against her nephew.100-5

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM lived at Venice and Padua, at each of which she bought a house.

SHORTPROSE.P: This move enabled her to pick up the threads with old friends, including Chiara Michiel and Algarotti, and to find new intimates in the Jacobite exiles Sir James and Lady Frances Steuart. She also developed new friendships, many of them by letter. But these years were embittered by enmity with the libertine coterie of the British Resident, John Murray (a crony of Casanova), and the British Consul, the art-collector Joseph Smith. Their whole circle teased and persecuted her as a learned lady and as an old woman, though their animus was probably political in origin.3: 111-278

During these years she self-identified as one of an oppressed group: that of old women. Jill Campbell has written about her old age in Defects: Engendering the Modern Body, edited by Helen Deutsch and Felicity Nussbaum, 2000.

The motive that finally propelled Lady Mary home to England after her years abroad was the fear, which she had begun to entertain even before her husband's death, that her son would succeed in getting the impressive Wortley Montagu fortune into his own hands, and cutting out his sister, Lady Bute, and her children. When he challenged his father's will he did so in his mother's name, and Lady Mary therefore felt that her presence in England was imperative.600-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM made her last journey, overland from Venice to Rotterdam and then by water to London.

SHORTPROSE.P: Europe was full of armies fighting the Seven Years' War; and once the battle zones were past she had to wait weeks to cross the Channel, the last leg of her journey, since its approaches were iced up.609-13

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM lived her last months in Great George Street, Hanover Square, London.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her daughter had found her a house, which she felt to be almost comically cramped and uncomfortable when compared with an Italian palazzo.
Her arrival caused something of a sensation. People flocked to visit her, as a relic from a more colourful past age.615-16

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM died of breast cancer in Great George Street, Hanover Square, London.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was buried in the vault at the fairly new Grosvenor Chapel nearby. The inscription put up by her daughter has been inaccessible for years, since the vault has been closed.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMWM, eighteenth-century woman of letters, identified herself as a writer, a sister of the quill3: 173 haunted by the daemon of poetry. She wrote poems, essays, fiction (including adult fairy-tale, oriental tale, and full-length mock romance), satire, a diary, a play, a political periodical, and a history of her own times. Not all of these survive. Best known in her lifetime for her poetry, she is today still best known for her letters.3: 173, 183

CHRONPROSE.PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY: The teenage Lady Mary Pierrepont (later LMWM) served a poetic and literary apprenticeship, evidenced in two surviving volumes of prose and verse.

P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: She seems to have circulated her writings among a group of young women including probably Mary Monck. She copied them in two surviving albums, from one of which pages were then cut out, apparently following a reprimand for writing.
P.PARCHIVALLOCATION: These volumes are now in the Harrowby MSS Trust, Sandon Hall, Staffordshire: 250, 251.

SHORTPROSE.P: They include a novel in five letters (Indamora to Lindamira); a verse-and-prose romance (The Adventurer), and poems in various pastoral and classical modes—epistles, lyrics, etc. The novel gives a voice to the silent confidante from Thomas Brown's Adventures of Lindamira, 1702 (one of Robert Adams Day's four best epistolary fictions before Richardson (others being by Catharine Trotter and Mary Davys).177. Indamora to Lindamira is modelled on Behn's Voyage to the Isle of Love, whose emblematic geography comes in turn from Scudéry's Clélie. Its male protagonist, Strephon, experiences love of an ideal (which nearly kills him with grief), love of an unworthy object (which introduces him to the torments of jealousy), and happy duplicitous love, which is interrupted when he accidentally sends each lady a love-letter intended for the other. He departs sadder but wiser from his experience of love: something not possible for a female protagonist. The poems bear the mark of Behn, Philips, and Cowley. They play with the ideas of love, pastoral retreat, and moral idealism. All except Indamora and The Adventurer remain (in 2007) unpublished.16ff

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Lady Mary Pierrepont (later LMWM) spent a week translating into English prose the Enchiridion of Epictetus.

P.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: She did this work in a solitude which her father imposed on her when he caught her in illicit correspondence with Edward Wortley Montagu.

SHORTPROSE.P: Epictetus was both a slave and a cripple. His philosophy, which insisted on the mind's capacity to rise above adverse circumstances, held considerable appeal for women writers of this period. (The best-known translation was that by Elizabeth Carter, published in April 1758).

P.TTONESTYLE: Lady Mary sent her translation straight off to Bishop Gilbert Burnet with a request (phrased with proper humility) that he should read and criticise it.
P.RRESPONSES: His answer does not survive, but he carefully read and revised about half her work.1: 44n2

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Lady Mary Pierrepont (later LMWM) began her negotiation by letter with her future husband, Edward Wortley Montagu.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was already by this date in correspondence with several female friends (not to mention her juvenile letters to her Pierrepont step-grandmother, none of which survive). She daringly initiated an exchange of direct—and illicit—courtship letters after the death of Edward's sister Anne, whom he had been using as an epistolary mouthpiece. Further letters to him survive from their early married life. Of those she wrote him after leaving England in 1739, by no means all are extant.

P.TTONESTYLE: The surviving courtship series covers every stage of their tortuous emotional exchange. Lady Mary tries hard to construct herself as a rational being facing a momentous choice of life, rather than as a girl in love, which would imply being instinctual and appetitive. She defends herself constantly, sometimes bitterly, against his accusations of bad conduct ranging from careless indecorums to heartless coquetry. She expresses love most clearly in the letters written soon after marriage, before the correspondence was taken over by business, domestic arrangements, and attempts to energise her husband's career. In middle and old age she wrote him largely duty letters concerned with such matters as health, dealing more in information than emotion. Within these limits their shared interests (in, for instance, literature, antiquarianism, or trade) could still provoke her to write to him in lively detail.

SHORTPROSE.P: Lost letters by LMWM hugely outnumber those which are extant. Evidence of lost correspondences exists sometimes in the form of mentions of them, by LMWM or others, and sometimes in the form of the summaries which she kept of letters posted. She kept such summaries of letters she actually sent from Turkey (which overlap only partially with what she later wrote up as a travel book), and of letters written late in her life, from Venice and Padua.xix-xx, 556

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM wrote her surviving letters on London society to her sister Lady Mar, exiled in Paris.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMWM's extant letters to her sister after the latter's mental breakdown are few and short.

P.TTONESTYLE: The 1720s series brilliantly anatomises the follies of upper-class London society.

CHRONPROSE.TTONESTYLE: LMWM wrote love-letters to Francesco Algarotti, many of them in French.

P.TTONESTYLE: The emotional outpouring of the early letters sounds unmediated; yet they are modelled on a style used in epistolary fiction by Behn and Haywood.

SHORTPROSE.P: She wrote later letters too to Algarotti, 1756-7, of friendship, paradox, and enlightenment speculation.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: During these years LMWM wrote her letters to Lady Pomfret.

P.TTONESTYLE: These are displays of learning, compliment, and sometimes satire, with a bluestocking tone.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: From these years date LMWM's surviving letters to her childhood friend Lady Oxford.

P.PNONSURVIVAL: She had been writing to Lady Oxford for years before this, but the earlier part of the correspondence does not survive.

P.TTONESTYLE: They are formal and dignified, but expressive of deep attachment.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM wrote her surviving letters to her daughter, Lady Bute.

SHORTPROSE.P: They were written from Avignon and northern Italy, and on her final journey home.

These letters suggest great intimacy of mind. LMWM offers her views on people, places, and books; about the education of girls and the reputation of women. She presents herself as who has learned wisdom through experience of the world (in addition to a loving, and occasionally self-justifying, mother and grandmother). At the same time the desire to win and hold her daughter's good opinion limits her self-revelation.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM wrote some of her best-known letters: those to her daughter about the education of her grand-daughters.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM wrote the letters in her last surviving important correspondence: with Sir James and Lady Frances Steuart.

SHORTPROSE.P: These letters construct and express the closest of confidential relationships with a philosopher and his wife: kindred spirits, though they were of her children's generation and of a political allegiance opposite to her own. They abound in wit, paradox, and the deliberate relation of impossibilities. It was to Lady Frances that LMWM wrote her last extant letter.

CHRONPROSE.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: LMWM's letters to Sir James and Lady Frances Steuart were printed as Original Letters, at Greenock in Scotland.

SHORTPROSE.P: The full title was Original Letters from the Right Honourable Lady Mary Wortley Montague, to Sir James & Lady Frances Steuart; also Memoirs and Anecdotes of those distinguished persons.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM wrote, ex tempore in Company in a Glass Window, a brief poem of aspiration to wifely virtue and discretion.

P.PANTHOLOGIZATION: This was much reprinted in periodicals and miscellanies,
P.RSHEINFLUENCED: often with an answer by an unidentified gentleman.

SHORTPROSE.P: This poem suggests that women are culpably hungry for flattery (as the poet's husband felt she often was); she declares herself willing to bear sole responsibility for her sexual reputation: it will be her own fault if a man gets close enough to cause any problems. It lifts a line from Dryden's Don Sebastian and comes close to echoing Sir Thomas Overbury's collection The Wife, 1613 (an echo much clearer in the printed form which diverges from MWM's own manuscript).355n Jessie Crabill has persuasively argued that in view of the general satirical tone of verses engraved on glass (for which diamond pencils were used) the poem's decorous stance should be taken as ironic.

PCIRCULATION.RRESPONSES: Its frequent copying and reprinting suggest that its virtuous sentiments were popular, and probably taken unironically.

CHRONPROSE.TINTERTEXTUALITY: LMWM wrote an epilogue (not used on stage) to Joseph Addison's famous tragedy, Cato.

SHORTPROSE.P: Cato opened in April 1713, but this epilogue was not used in the theatre.

P.TTONESTYLE: It strikes—as was normal for an epilogue at this time—a note of modern cynicism, not only contrasting with the highflown idealism of the play, but suggesting that noble characters like this are fools.

CHRONPROSE.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: The Spectator printed as its number 573 LMWM's contribution, an autobiographical letter from an imaginary recasting of the stereotypical predatory widow.

P.PAUTHORSHIP: Montagu was the only woman among The Spectator's many distinguished contributors, unrecognised as such until the twentieth century.

P.TCHARACTERIZATION: Her widow is President of a club of widows which had featured in the recent number 561, by Addison. Montagu's heroine, sold into marriage at an early age, has resolved to exploit as the only alternative to being exploited. None of her deceased husbands, she says, was worth mourning. One of them, chosen for looking sexy, proved such a bore that she regretted his feeble predecessor. When in danger of being starved by a miser, she began spending money so furiously as to kill him with shock. She is unique in her period as an unabashedly selfish survivor who never gets her comeuppance.

LMWM, Court Poems, 1716

TVOICENARRATION.TCHARACTERIZATION: LMWM wrote her Eclogues or mock eclogues, a series of six poems featuring speakers from the competitive Court world in place of pastoral rustics.

P.PAUTHORSHIP:
These poems have been linked since first publication with the names of Pope and Gay. But there are many reasons to think that the contributions of these two were far smaller than has been supposed. Montagu had written the first (Roxana, which later becameMonday), within a few weeks of arriving in London in very early 1715, when it is not certain she had yet met either of the other poets. Her version of Friday (a differing version of which was later printed among Gay's works) is a female-centred protest about the workings of contemporary marriage. And Warburton printed Thursday as Pope's merely because Pope kept a copy. The existence of contested endings to Wednesday hints at Montagu's effort to prevent her literary associates from taking over her work.93-4, 104ff184ff
Pat Rogers and Paul Baines disagree with Grundy: they write, in 2007, that [s]cholars now generally hold that Friday is a poem by Gay, written by him before Montagu decided to fill in the rest of the week.81

CHRONPROSE.PMODEOFPUBLICATION: LMWM's satirical mock-eclogues Monday, Thursday, and Friday were illicitly printed by Edmund Curll as Court Poems.

SHORTPROSE.P:
These poems were three of the six eclogues (one for each weekday) preserved in the poetry album which Montagu claimed as her own, and printed as Six Town Eclogues in 1747. Monday, the first poem both in date of composition and in Curll's volume, had been shown about at Court while LMWM was ill with smallpox, compromising her relationship with Princess Caroline. Curll's introduction speculated that the author might be either Montagu, Gay, or Pope. Pope (perhaps protecting Gay rather than Lady Mary) took a barbarous109ff revenge on Curll by giving him (or pretending to have given him) an emetic, and publishing two ribald pamphlets about the alleged episode.109-10
Pat Rogers and Paul Baines believe there can be little doubt that the emetic was actually administered.83

All the mock eclogues target actual individuals and refer to events which were gossip of the day. Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Satturday are monologues with variously unreliable narrators, while Tuesday and Thursday take the other traditional eclogue form of competitive dialogue. The speaker of Monday is a duchess passed over for an appointment at the court of Caroline, Princess of Wales, who relieves her feelings by spiteful comment on the princess and her court; that of Wednesday is a wife who maintains that she wants her non-marital love to remain platonic. That of Friday is a mistress facing the grave humiliation of having her lover turn back to his wife, and that of Satturday is a beauty facing the worse humiliation of losing her looks. The two rakes of Tuesday, boasting their conquests over compliant upper-class women, were identified by readers as two future dukes.
One of them, John Campbell, in time became the uncle of novelist Elizabeth Gunning and the grandfather of sculptor and novelist Anne Damer. The other, Algernon Seymour, Lord Hertford, was the recent bridegroom of Frances Thynne, who became known as both patron and writer under her title of Lady Hertford. The female rivals of Thursday, who argue over the relative merits of love and card-playing as absorbing hobbies, were similarly identified as Montagu herself and her friend Lady Bristol. Satturday—which closes the series with a lament by Flavia, who has lost her beauty to smallpox—is as much a satire and a social criticism as all the others. Flavia shares Lady Mary's predicament and her thirst for admiration, but lacks her toughness and her intellect. These attitudes voiced in these highly sophisticated dramatised poems cannot be adequately read at face value. In every case the speaker is influenced by some personal predicament and by response to a competitive, commodified social world.

P.RRESPONSES: The earliest readers of the first, illicitly-published selection of these poems apparently took them straight: the tirade of Roxana in Monday against the court which has rejected her was taken as unproblematically reflecting the views of the author, rather than as raillery, or implied praise through attack by the voice of stupidity.
P.RPENALTIES: Montagu was reported to be in disgrace at court as a consequence.103
P.RRESPONSES: The Eclogues, more usually called by the non-authorial title of Town Eclogues, nevertheless soon came to occupy the core of LMWM's reputation as a poet. They have retained that position, though the tendency of anthologies to select only one of them, generally Satturday, militates against an informed reading.

SHORTPROSE.P: Only one letter which LMWM sent through the post during the period of the Embassy Letters is extant in manuscript form. Addressed to Frances Hewet and sent from Adrianople on 1 April [1717], it was offered for sale by Bernard Quaritch in early 2007 for £5,800.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM dated the edited letters making up her manuscript travel book about Europe, Turkey, and the Mediterranean: her Embassy Letters.

SHORTPROSE.P: She altered or misremembered the date she gave the final letter in her book; the corresponding actual letter could not have been written on that day. Mary Astell added her feminist preface, in prose and verse, on 18 December 1724 and 31 May 1725, at a time when LMWM was evidently circulating this work in manuscript. 1: 466-8

PMODEOFPUBLICATION.RLANDMARKTEXT: Making posthumous and unauthorised use of her name, Becket and De Hondt published LMWM's Embassy Letters as Letters . . . written during her travels.

P.PMODEOFPUBLICATION: The manuscript had been transcribed in Rotterdam while in the custody of the Rev. Benjamin Sowden.

PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY.PMOTIVES: Montagu, in confiding it to Sowden on 11 December 1761, seems to have aimed at just such an outcome.

PMODEOFPUBLICATION.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: This was followed in 1764 by a stylish piracy, allegedly printed by A. Homer and P. Milton for a publisher in St Paul's Churchyard, London: probably really published at Edinburgh.

PEDITIONS.PAUTHORSHIP: This added spurious material to the genuine letters; in 1767 Becket and De Hondt issued a revised edition incorporating the new material, which therefore came to be accepted as genuine.

SHORTPROSE.P: Montagu is an acute observer the various Christian European cultures, as well as of Islamic Europe and Turkey, and the classically-haunted Mediterranean. She tends to approve Protestant or republican states, and to disparage anything ancien régime (she admires technological advance, despises gothic architecture, and never tires of poking fun at Catholic reverence for relics), yet she often writes enthusiastically of the charm of individual monarchs. She delights in the fantastic opulence of Turkey (which, she says, suggests that oriental romances are actually realistic) yet describes daily life and manners there in almost sociological style. She evidently excised repetitions and personal passages from her actual letters, but retained a general aptness of material to recipient, writing to her sister of clothes and social customs, to the abbé Antonio Conti her Enlightenment cultural and religious analysis, and to Pope of literary matters. She enters with gusto into correcting the errors of previous travellers to Turkey, and delights in taking the part of Islam against Christendom, especially in disputing the generally accepted view that Europe shows its superiority in the status accorded its women. She notes that Turkish married women own property. One of these letters admiringly describes, in careful empirical detail, the eastern medical practice of inoculation against smallpox, and declares her intention of one day introducing it to England. Her openness to other cultures suffered a regrettable lapse in North Africa, where she seemed blind to the humanity of the local people , as she was nowhere else.

P.RRESPONSES: The praise by Astell, and by an anonymous poet who also attached a compliment to the manuscript, shows a recognition that this was a landmark text in women's writing.

A considerable critical literature has grown up around it since, which focuses on the Turkish part of the letters and often ignores the European part. LMWM's famous set-piece description of the women's public baths at Sofia (not, as often said, at Adrianople) has attracted particular attention, most of it from a post-colonial or a queer angle. While it is of course true that Montagu could not entirely detach herself from that European assumption of cultural superiority which she overtly opposed, it is also true that historical contexts—the Turkish empire, currently more immediately impressive than Britain's New World territories, and the prevailingly European ethnicity of upper-class Turks—are insufficiently taken into account in post-colonial comment. Alison Winch has recently put forward a lesbian reading of this letter which supposes that Montagu was flirting with the Lady — to whom it is (in the transcription though not necessarily in life) addressed, and which argues that the letter and Montagu's writings and reputation in general, her accretion of anecdote and rumour, her fantastical life-writing, influenced Virginia Woolf's Orlando in various details as well as in the passage where the male poet Orlando, British ambassador to Constantinople, is shockingly reborn as a woman writer52ff

CHRONPROSE.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: LMWM, past eight months pregnant and sitting in a summer-house at the British Embassy palace at Constantinople, composed a rural-retreat poem about her garden setting.

SHORTPROSE.P: She addressed the poem as an epistle, probably to her uncle William Feilding; her recent editors follow her manuscript in titling it Constantinople To [William Feilding]. It was picked up for printing by Anthony Hammond in his collection A New Miscellany, published on 19 May 1720.206

It opens by recalling one of her juvenile poems: a work in the My Wish genre, in which she had prayed conventionally for a homely spot in which to enjoy retirement. Her prayer, she says, has been answered with the addition of the idyllic spring-in-winter, the splendid appearance and stirring history of Constantinople, which she then describes as encircling her refuge. She meditates on the dangers of public life for a woman, and hints at her pregnancy only in an image of one generation of flowers succeeding to another.

PPERIODICALPUBLICATION.PAUTHORSHIP: The Flying-Post printed LMWM's polemical essay A Plain Account of the Innoculating of the Small Pox, as by a Turkey Merchant.

SHORTPROSE.P: It is not clear who arranged for this publication.

P.TTONESTYLE: The essay not only defends inoculation but attacks the Western medical profession as caring only for profit and not at all for the welfare of patients. Its furious and defensive tone is unique among pro-inoculation publicists (most of whom were studiously courteous and rational in argument) and deliberately, disturbingly in tune with the hysterical denunciations of the anti-inoculators.

CHRONPROSE.PAUTHORSHIP: LMWM and Mary Astell wrote, on opposite sides of the same sheet of paper, polemical poems on the death of the fourteen-year-old bride Eleanor Bowes (née Verney), denouncing the institution of marriage.

SHORTPROSE.P:
According to the surviving manuscript, the two women produced their verse responses on the very day that Eleanor Bowes was said (years later, by the cynical Horace Walpole) to die of the violence of the Bridegroom's embraces.241
The bridegroom, George Bowes, a business associate of Lady Mary's husband, was known to be a rake, but he seems to have loved his child bride. After her death he remained unmarried for twenty years; he gave his only child her name (along with that of his second wife), and he planned a chapel in Eleanor's memory in which he would be buried himself.5 It seems that they produced their occasional poems together, since the original paper with their two handwritings survives as Daly MS 5m 50/2237, Hampshire Record Office. LMWM's On the Death of Mrs Bowes was printed in The Weekly Journal or Saturdays-Post, 26 December 1724, and was several times reprinted and anthologised. It followed within six months of another fiercely feminist poem by her, Epistle from Mrs Yonge to her Husband.

In Mrs Bowes Montagu (unlike Astell) glorifies the initial raptures of marriage. Both agree that this girl with married life before her is better off dead. LMWM's Epistle from Mrs Yonge is a complaint from an unfaithful wife who is being publicly, scandalously divorced (to his great financial gain) by her equally unfaithful husband: it is a clearly and passionately articulated protest against the sexual double standard.

P.RRESPONSES: Montagu's Mrs Bowes drew much hostile comment, and seldom appeared in print without some accompanying answer rebuking the poet for lewdness.
The feminist critique voiced in Mrs Yonge was either not circulated by its author or not attractive to collectors or anthologists; the poem remained unpublished and unknown till 1972.

Whatever specific events in their separate material and emotional lives may have precipitated the shredding of LMWM's reputation by Pope, it seems safe to suppose that his actions were both a response to her writings, and an indignant denial of her claim to the identity of writer. As in all his attacks on writing women, however, he focussed on the woman, not the author.

CHRONPROSE.RRESPONSES: Pope published what seems to have been the first salvo in his prolonged literary attack on LMWM: The Capon's Tale, which accuses her of passing off her lampoons as other people's.

SHORTPROSE.P: From now until April 1735 he pursued her with one printed insult after another.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The earliest form of Pope's Dunciad launched his second attack on LMWM, implying her membership in the class of rapacious whores.

P.RRESPONSES: The Dunciad provoked a storm of pro- and anti-Pope ephemera. Many on each side used Montagu's name as a missile, since she was widely recognised as a leading figure among those whom Pope had injured. Such references were demeaning to her rank and reputation; and since Pope believed her to be the author of several attacks on him, his rancour against her grew.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Pope attacked LMWM's husband's business practices in his Epistle to Lord Bathurst.
Pope's Second Satire of the Second Book of Horace attacked LMWM and her husband together.
Pope's Sober Advice from Horace attacked LMWM (under a variety of ingenious but permeable nicknames): to be even suggested in a poem of this pornographic tone was damaging.

CHRONPROSE.RRESPONSES: Pope's Epistle to Dr Arbuthnot made a particularly strong and memorable attack on LMWM's friend Hervey and also herself.

SHORTPROSE.P: The poem was, of course, addressing a man who had been LMWM's close associate. This time she responded with a letter to Arbuthnot, designed to be shown to Pope, to rebuke and to hurt him in return. It seems to have made no difference.

CHRONPROSE.RRESPONSES: Pope's An Epistle to a Lady. Of the Characters of Women delineated a controlled and submissive female ideal (and again attacked LMWM).

P.RRESPONSES: Lady Mary is made by implicit allusion the converse of the ideal woman whom Pope addresses. The allusions are the more pointed since their moon-and-sun imagery retools and reverses some of his previous flattery of her.

SHORTPROSE.P: The second volume which Pope added to his Works in April 1735 (completing a set whose first volume he had sent to LMWM as a tribute in the days of his adoration) included his revised versions of earlier texts; several changes incorporate fresh insults to her.

Before she did so in public, LMWM replied in private to Pope's attacks, in responses to and imitations of his Dunciad. Undertaken in collaboration with her younger cousin Henry Fielding, these remained unpublished during her lifetime.

HEADING.TITLE: Verses to the Imitator of Horace

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: LMWM and Hervey, Verses to the Imitator of Horace, 1733

TINTERTEXTUALITY.PAUTHORSHIP: Verses Address'd to the Imitator of Horace, a satiric attack on and riposte to Pope which was probably composed by LMWM and Lord Hervey, appeared in two separate, anonymous, folio editions.

P.PEDITIONS: Each issue of To the Imitator was priced at sixpence. One appeared through a trade publisher, James Roberts, and one through a mercury, Anne Dodd. Both these were pamphlet-sellers offering authors the option of remaining untraceable. The Dodd version was entitled Verses Address'd to the Imitator of the First Satire of the Second Book of Horace, described as by a Lady. The Roberts version, unascribed, was entitled To the Imitator of the Satire of the Second Book of Horace. Differences between the two versions are very slight.

PMOTIVES.PAUTHORSHIP: This poem is almost certainly the joint work of LMWM and Lord Hervey. It is a hostile reply to Pope's most recent attack on LMWM, in his First Satire of the Second Book of Horace, published on 15 February 1733. Pope mentioned Hervey casually as a feeble poet; on Montagu he was highly specific and insulting. Arguing that everyone possesses some natural offensive weapon, he says that Sappho's enemies will end up P-x'd by her Love, or libell'd by her Hate.265 LMWM did not have the great pox—syphilis—to communicate; but she had indeed communicated smallpox, in the beneficent form of inoculation.

P.RESEARCHNOTE: SRF:para has an odd blend of reception (Pope's response to her) and motives. IMG: yes but needed I think.

P.PADVERTISING: Newspapers carried competitive advertisements for the two versions.

PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY.PCIRCULATION: Extant manuscripts (three known, besides Hervey's scribal copy) suggest that the poem circulated before being printed.

P.PAUTHORSHIP: It would be tempting but wrong to associate one version with each of the putative authors. In fact Montagu and Hervey each had links with both Dodd and Roberts. All the evidence points at collaboration between these two authors, but it does not amount to proof. In 1735 Lord Oxford named a third collaborator, William Wyndham, whose wife (Lady Delorain) Pope had attacked; but if he played any part it was probably a small one.

P.PEDITIONS: The Dodd version went through several slightly revised editions before and after 16 January 1735, when a Fifth Edition Corrected was advertised in response to Pope's Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot—a poem addressed to a former friend of LMWM. This epistle draws heavily on the Verses, borrowing its imagery for its savage portrait of Hervey as Sporus.

SHORTPROSE.P: Besides debating the Verses' authorship, critics have debated over who put them into print. The answer to this riddle is almost certainly that Pope did. Circulating in manuscript at Court, they encouraged highly influential readers to collude in deriding him. Once conveyed into print by Pope's typically cloak-and-dagger methods, they appeared to readers to legitimate his complaints and to prove he had been right to call Montagu a libeller.184

The Verses are the most brilliant of all the many satirical attacks on Pope, and one of the most offensive. They zero in on his physical disability, and claim that it is the sign of his deformed mind. They deny that he resembles Horace, or that he has talent, or that his attacks perturb his victims. They do not impugn his masculinity, like other attacks, but his humanity. They compare him to noxious but not dangerous animals (a wasp, a porcupine), and finally to the biblical Cain, who killed his brother. Their style is rousing, but controlled, with greater economy and forcefulness than Hervey achieves when writing alone. Though their debating tone owes something to Pope's own, it is deliberately weightier and more judicial. The poem's effect depends on the reader's willingness to enjoy the spectacle of combat, the ringing tones of self-righteous anger.

P.RRESPONSES: According to a delighted Hervey, Pope was infuriated. Swift thought the Verses were badly written.
Montagu's granddaughter Lady Louisa Stuart thought that for high-born writers to jeer at Pope's family was shameful.
P.RESEARCHNOTE: kdc; how is Louisa Stuart's response adfeminam? Her concern has more to do with class than gender by the sounds of it. img: I think it's adFeminam because addressing LMWM as an individual by addressing her class, which sets her off from other attackers of Pope.
P.RRESPONSES: On the whole LMWM's literary reputation has suffered from her virulence here. Readers have disliked the Verses and blamed their author for perceived ethical failings.

Pope's virulence has met with much the same response; but Lady Mary's gender has made her seem more blameworthy, because lacking in attributes of sympathy which many have regarded as indispensable for a woman.

SHORTPROSE.P: LMWM must have written her (arguably even more trenchant) attack, P[ope] to Bolingbroke, by June 1735; but she did not publish it. Bolingbroke, Tory politician, charismatic rake, and serial political turncoat, was a man she personally hated.279

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: LMWM, The Dean's Provocation for Writing the Lady's Dressing-Room, 1734

PAUTHORSHIP.TINTERTEXTUALITY: LMWM's lampoon on Swift appeared as an anonymous folio, The Dean's Provocation for Writing the Lady's Dressing-Room. A Poem.

P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: Her holograph (one of two copies) calls it The Reasons that Induce'd Dr S[wift] to write a Poem call'd the Lady's Dressing room.
P.PMODEOFPUBLICATION: There is no indication of whether she or someone else arranged for its publication.

TGENREISSUE.TINTERTEXTUALITY: Her own title makes her own poem an answer to one of Swift's most notorious productions.

TTONESTYLE.TINTERTEXTUALITY: In a brilliant pastiche of his own stylistic habits and his scatological gusto,

P.TTHEMETOPIC: Montagu represents him as an impotent lecher whose revenge when mocked by a woman is to write misogynist poetry.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her poetry as a whole is conspicuous for its versatility. Her major early influences (Katherine Philips and Abraham Cowley) were succeeded by Dryden. (She always denied any influence from Pope.) But she was extremely well-read among lesser-known writers, and this shows up in the range of styles that she commands. Often moved to poetry by some outside stimulus or provocation, she always writes strongly and often movingly, with unfailing intelligence of thought.

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: LMWM, Simplicity, 1734

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM wrote a free translation of Le Jeu de l'amour et du hasard, a comedy by Marivaux; she titled it Simplicity.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She probably wrote it just after a French company had presented the original in London, and while her own daughter was enmeshed in the stress and anxiety of courtship—stresses and anxiety which the play delightfully and good-humouredly resolves.
Marivaux acknowledged the indebtedness of his drama (as well as his fiction) to the English tradition.

P.PPERFORMANCE: A production of Simplicity which toured England in the 1988 offered a lively interpretation, but it bracketed the play itself between excerpts from MWM's letters (courtship letters as prologue, satiric comments on other people's marriages as epilogue), thus inappropriately suggesting her identity with her own heroine. Another production, at the Orange Tree Theatre in 2003, was accompanied by Scenes from the Life of Lady Mary extracted from a play about her by Erica Gordon, Chasing the Golden Sun.

SHORTPROSE.P: In this Marivaux play a young lady exchanges clothes with her maid, with a view to learning the real character of the suitor her father has provided—who, however, has had the same idea, and exchanged clothes with his own servant. The most striking features of Montagu's adaptation are the unusually benevolent, non-authoritarian attitude of the heroine's father and brother, and her horror and shame when she believes that she has fallen in love with a servant. This catches more clearly than Marivaux the anxiety felt by women of the time that their sexual feelings could render them liable to social damnation.

Joanna Hole, the performer who discovered the play and arranged its production in 1988, called Montagu's sense of humour in it gem-like. I defy anyone not to be amused. . . . had she been alive now, I am sure she would have been among our leading sitcom writers. A hoped-for television version, however, did not materialise.What's On 1

CHRONPROSE.TINTERTEXTUALITY: LMWM published her periodical The Nonsense of Common-Sense, a riposte to the anti-government Common Sense.

P.PATTITUDES: Its banner proclaimed: To be continued as long as the Author thinks fit, and the Public likes it.105
P.PMODEOFPUBLICATION: She saw to the publishing arrangements herself, but covered her tracks by using the trade publisher James Roberts.
P.PAUTHORSHIP: Her authorship remained unsuspected until the 1940s.

SHORTPROSE.P: She mixed her ingeniously satirical aspersions against the Opposition with economic analysis of wages and interest rates, strong feminist argument about the status of women, and an extended joke about opera singers.371-8

P.PATTITUDES: Little of LMWM's remarkable fictional output can be dated. It is probable that she wrote much that she did not preserve, since she comments dismissively on her own indulgence in this activity.
P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: It seems that she was working on her longest surviving piece (written in French, and published in her Romance Writings as Princess Docile), during her years in Avignon, and again towards the end of her life.

P.TINTERTEXTUALITY: Her choice of genres came from her reading in French, not English, fiction,
though Louisa (one of two survivors from a cycle of tales set at the court of Louis XIV of France) also sounds like a response to Richardson's Pamela.

Princess Docile, too, makes sardonic allusion to Pamela and to Fénelon's Télémaque (a propos Docile's education) and to Marie-Madeleine de Lafayette's La Princesse de Clèves (a propos the end of her story).

P.TPLOT: In each of the two surviving court tales a passionately loving woman (one a princess, one a poor orphan) is destroyed by the same cold and sexually predatory man.
P.TGENREISSUE: As well as the court tales, LMWM also wrote a most unusual oriental tale, and many short fictions including two fictionalised autobiographies. One of these takes the form of a satirical fairy-tale, which (along with the philosophical conte and the picaresque) is one of the possible generic descriptions of the anti-romance Princess Docile.

P.TPLOT: Docile her longest work of prose fiction, is also autobiographical in its scarifying yet comic account of the naive and idealistic Docile's repeated victimisation. Endowed with perfect docility as a fairy gift, educated first by an ascetic hermit and then by a philosophe with high notions of honour, Docile is an innocent in a dog-eat-dog world. Rejected by her mother and cynically exploited by the first person she loves (the courtier marquise d'Artifice) she loses the real love of her life (a prince visiting from the planet Venus) and marries the high-minded, misogynist, bullying Prince Sombre, who abandons her when he suspects her quite unjustly of infidelity. After an interlude in a guilt-free kingdom of pleasure which does not interest her idealistic nature, she finds herself patiently, deceitfully wooed by a cold and calculating man to whom, gradually, she gives her mature love. Among the names of this unusual character (a self-made gentleman) is Count Fortunatus—the name given in Delarivier Manley'a New Atalantis to the future Duke of Marlborough (whom, however, Montagu admired). Docile loses her kingdom, and is left at the end of the story a recluse, impeccable in conduct but sullied in reputation, after rejecting a life of pleasure in various heavily compromised guises offered by various male characters.

SHORTPROSE.P: No evidence is known that LMWM circulated Docile or her other fictions among her friends, as she did some of her other writings. It not only remained unpublished, but was virtually ignored by researchers among her manuscripts.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: LMWM drew up, in Italian, some form of the document later called her Italian Memoir.

PMOTIVES.TGENREISSUE: This unusual autobiographical text was designed as the foundation of a court case against Count Ugolino Palazzi.

P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: The surviving manuscript is not in Montagu's own hand.

P.TTONESTYLE: The Italian in which it is written retains many of the stylistic characteristics of her English writings, as well as some local characteristics of that part of North Italy which she knew best.
P.TCHARACTERIZATION: The document seeks to present Palazzi as an emotional blackmailer, who takes pains to establish that he is driven not directly by bald financial greed but by the constant, expensive demands of maintaining his honour, and herself as one whose patrician and philosophic indifference to mere material considerations is high-minded rather than incompetent. Its tone remains matter-of-fact even when its subject-matter verges on the gothic: a hooded monk, an armed interceptor.

PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY.RDESTRUCTIONOFWORK: LMWM's lifelong diary was burned in two instalments. When she eloped she left the early portion behind, and her sister burned it lest it should fall into her father's hands. Just before she died the rest of it came into her daughter's possession (whether by gift or involuntary discovery is not clear). Her daughter treasured it for years, but gave orders when she felt near death herself that it should be destroyed.

SHORTPROSE.P: From Lady Louisa Stuart's report of the first volume to be written after its author's marriage (the only one she was permitted to read) it sounds as if it contained reportage rather than introspection, in the manner of Saint-Simon rather than Boswell.

CHRONPROSE.PEDITIONS: LMWM's Works appeared in five volumes, very badly edited by James Dallaway, in a bid by her family to head off an unauthorised edition.

P.PEDITIONS: The first printing, on expensive paper, was quickly followed by a cheaper reprint which corrected some of the more glaring errors. A family-edited Letters and Works followed in December 1836, dated on its title-page 1837. Though said to be edited by Lord Wharncliffe (the head of the family), it was largely the work of LMWM's youngest grand-daughter, Lady Louisa Stuart. Dallaway's errors as to date and place of letters were more nearly eradicated in the edition by W. Moy Thomas in 1861, the best nineteenth-century edition, which had wide circulation and several re-issues. The 1866 reprint was once more reissued by Cambridge University Press in 2011,online and in print-on-demand format.

Montagu's first scholarly editor was Robert Halsband, with The Nonsense of Common-Sense (Northwestern University Press, 1947), Complete Letters, 1965-7, and Essays and Poems and Simplicity, A Comedy, 1977. In the last Halsband collaborated with Isobel Grundy, who edited Montagu's Romance Writings in 1996.627-8

SHORTPROSE.P:
For centuries LMWM has been interpreted and re-interpreted, judged less often as writer than as an exemplar of the unacceptable female. Wordsworth judged her to have been destined for something much higher and better than she became.1: 474 Regular re-issues of her works during the Victorian period received long and detailed reviews in the standard journals, but reviewers evaluated her conduct rather than her writings. Her appeal to women of progressive and feminist cast is instanced in the fact that Elizabeth Robins wrote about her in 1899 under the title A Modern Woman Born 1689,Chronology as well as in George Paston's life of her, 1907. Meanwhile the many fictional treatments of MWM (following those of contemporaries like Pope, or Cudworth Bruch who eulogised her in his Triumph of Inoculation, 1767) include L. E. L.'s remarkable rendering in Ethel Churchill (1837). She has been a major figure recently in The Speckled Monster by Jennifer Lee Carroll, 2003 (about the campaign for smallpox inoculation), and a lively minor one in Sophie Gee's The Scandal of the Season, 2007 (about the real-life story narrated in Pope's The Rape of the Lock). Linda France in The Toast of the Kit-Cat Club, A Life of Lady Mary Wortley Montagu in Eleven Chapters, 2005, extraordinarily transforms Montagu's life into a sequence of piercing small poems. A still more surprising testimonial to Montagu's popularity is her appearance in Hello magazine on 25 July 2006, in an article by Cristina Morato introduced by boxes reading Women Ahead of Their Time and A Writer Who Defied Convention to Unveil the Mysteries of the Exotic East.96
This piece is lavishly illustrated but none of the portraits of Montagu is authentic.
